params.note: KO to compound heterozygous KO or heterozygous KO can obscure phenotype-genotype associations, particularly for genes with dosage-sensitive effects. Follow-up validation using isogenic homozygous or heterozygous KO lines is critical for clarifying the effect of complete or partial loss of the candidate genes.

Organoids lack vascularization and cross-talk between brain regions. Assembloid generation is laborious, limiting some readouts and large-scale studies. Studies often require >10 weeks of in vitro differentiation.
This protocol provides a powerful tool for exploring complex neurodevelopmental processes in a human-relevant context.
We use a hiPS cell line that stably expresses Cas9 under a Tet-off system. Gene-editing efficiency was validated by a GFP self-cutting assay.
Cas9 function may vary in postmitotic cells. Virus-infected hiPS cells (with sgRNA and Cas9 expression) were maintained in culture for ~10 d to ensure gene editing.
For experiments editing postmitotic cells, including neurons, it is crucial to validate Cas9 function in the cell type of interest.
We focused on interneuron generation and migration in the forebrain as screen readouts.
We engineered a hiPS cell line to stably express eGFP under the control of a validated Dlxi1/2b enhancer, labeling medial ganglionic eminence-derived cell lineage.
Interneurons in hSO are marked as Dlxi1/2b::eGFP+.

For the interneuron generation screen, sgRNA enrichment was assessed by comparing sorted Dlxi1/2b::eGFP+ and Dlxi1/2b::eGFPâˆ’ populations in hSO immediately after patterning, when ~25% of cells had acquired interneuron identity.

Maintaining sufficient library representation is essential for reproducibility of pooled CRISPR screens, especially given inter-hiPS cell line variability for neural organoid generation.
Actual library representation may be lower than theoretically calculated in long-term cultures modeling dynamic developmental processes. Increasing library representation improves screen robustness.
During neural induction, differentiation, and patterning, neural organoids tend to fuse. Fused organoids are routinely separated to improve culture quality.
Xanthan gum polymers can be incorporated to avoid organoid fusion.
Large organoid clusters can impede cellular growth and result in unwanted cell death.
Harsh dissociation of organoids and assembloids can induce cell death, especially in long-term cultures. Papain concentration and incubation time were optimized to minimize cell death.
